desc.size: Shrub, 2.5 - 5 m tall and as wide. Graceful, broadly spreading, round-topped, with arching branches.

part.partText: rounded, brownish gray, smooth, with lenticels.
plump, pointed; scales reddish brown, overlapping.
opposite, stalked, medium to dark green, 4 - 8 cm long, to 3 cm wide, egg-shaped to lance-shaped, base tapering or rounded, tip pointed, margins non-toothed, smooth.
borne in a large, loose, 10 - 15 cm long branched inflorescence; purple-lilac, 7 - 8 mm long, tubular, 4-lobed, fragrant.
is not produced on this species; the plant is sterile.

similarSpecies.comments: In general, the buds of Syringa x chinensis are smaller and more refined than those of S. vulgaris. It also exhibits more profuse flowering than S. vulgaris. The leaves of S. x chinensis are smooth, unlike S. velutina, whose leaves are densely hairy underneath (usually).

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Often planted as an ornamental, and may persist after homesite abandonment. In general, Syringa species thrive best in moist soils.

notes.comments: Syringa x chinensis is a hybrid between S. persica and S. vulgaris. The common name “Chinese Lilac” came from the mistaken belief that the plant came from China. It actually originated in France.

etymology.comments: Syringa means lilac. It derives from the Greek word syrinx (pipe), and refers to the hollow stems. Chinensis means Chinese.
